author: swwolfe
title: Fallingwater a hit!
review: I've been a long time fan of Frank Lloyd Wright's work - and have visited Fallingwater numerous times in various seasons of the year - and Lego got this set absolutely right!  I was disappointed with the other Architecture sets in that they did not offer enough detail - this set does not disappoint in that respect.  This set was challenging to assemble - and it is a bonus that the sections fit together to offer a chance to see inside the design and structural elements.  I hope that Lego continues this Architectural series - and with as much or more detail as shown in this set.

author: enki_0042
title: Absolutely fantastic
review: As a static model, the aesthetics of this set is amazing. It;s definitely the most beautiful set I own, and a great building experience. However, if it's playability you're after, rather buy a Creator house...

author: Be_Burger
title: Fantastic Fallingwater
review:
Fallingwater is an INCREDIBLE build for anyone, especially for Frank Lloyd Wright fans. Despite its $100 price tag, it is full of lots of extremely useful plates and tiles in tan, trans-clear, and a few in dark green and dark bluish gray too! It is extremely cleverly made and will impress anyone. You build it in levels so that you have the base, and then the different floors can slide out and in, but it is so well constructed that it is not fragile to move around. This is definitely a great set for any architecture fan, but, if you are looking for something more "playable", you should stick with a Creator house like others have mentioned, there are NO minifigures here, and not much to play with.

Overall, its a great set that anyone will love.

author: mathew
title: Monochrome Masterpiece
review:
Adam Reed Tucker took a monochromatic approach when interpreting Frank Lloyd Wright's Fallingwater.  Utilizing mostly tan tiles, the final result resembles a sculpture more than a scaled model.  If it were not for the dark green 1x1 bricks that simulate trees, you might think that it was chiseled straight from a single slab of tan ABS.  

With a fun build there is a flow that happens.  The instructions almost disappear and it's just you and the bricks.  Fallingwater is one those builds.  Limited brick variety.  No fiddly technic.  Lots of stacking.  Put some music on and you're good to go.  

The spiral bound instruction book is great and I wish Lego would do this for all $100 or more sets (Robie House for example).  Speaking of value:  At $100 this set is expensive.  Is it worth it?  I would say yes if you can afford it.  Despite being smaller and having fewer pieces it does have a higher intangible value than other Lego sets in the same price range.  I'm sure the packaging and licensing fees have a lot to do with it.   I paid around $60 which I'm quite happy with hence the better than average value rating.

Pictures don't do this set justice.  You really have to admire it in the third dimension to appreciate its beauty and craftsmanship.   Highly recommended.

author: Brickdroid
title: A Beautiful Recreation of an Architectural Landmark
review:
If you don't want my entire, long winded review of Fallingwater, here you go: buy it. Now, onto the actual review.  I have always been a fan of lego.  The way that those wonderful little bricks click together just feels right to me.  Of course, when I started building non-duplo sets at the age of 6, I was naturally attracted to themes like star wars and exo-force where I could recreate huge, epic battles of good and evil, and, when they were released, all of the Indiana Jones sets, where I could have my adventurer evade deadly traps and beat the bad guys to the treasure.  The possibilities were endless!  However, I started to like those sets less and less.  By the time that I was 11, Exo-Force and Indiana Jones had been discontinued, and I'd noticed a decline in quality in the Star Wars sets. However, I don't think that they actually got worse.  I just didn't love recreating those immense battles like I used to.  My tastes were maturing, and, as if they read my mind, lego came out with the sets to match: the Architecture line.   I got this set for Christmas and I got straight to work.  For those who don't know, the set "Fallingwater" is a recreation of the famous architectural landmark of the same name.  Did this set fill its huge, metaphorical shoes? Let's find out.

Box/Instructions

The box and instruction booklet really set the tone for the amount of quality that I could expect from this set.  The box was extremely high quality, and was made so that you didn't have to rip it open to get all of your parts out. There was a tab that you only had to pull out, and the box would open like a book.  Speaking of books, the instruction manual for this set was also extremely nice. The cover and the pages were made out of extremely nice paper, and crossed the border between "instruction book" and an actual book.  In fact, the first few pages showed pictures of the actual building, and the architectural layouts for the building.

Parts

There is very little to actually say about the parts.  They are your standard tan, grey, green and transparent pieces, but they work very well for the set, and they could not have done better with any other pieces.

Minifigures

There are no minifigures in "Fallingwater".

The build

The build was one of the more challenging that I have embarked on, mainly because of the lack of variety in the pieces.  It get's very hard to discern one tan piece from the other, and if you make a mistake with a flat piece, they can be very hard to remove.  Because of this lack of variety, you may want to play music during the build or you could get very bored.

The completed model

There is only one word that properly describes this model: beautiful. It is currently sitting on my desk, and it looks absolutely fantastic.  The use of the flat transparent pieces for the river makes it look stunning, especially under a light.  Everything is perfect in terms of proportions, and aesthetically, this model just can't be beat.  It is very simple, but very effective.  Everything about this model is just smooth.

Summary

If you want to get the basic gist of this whole summary, it's right here: Fallingwater is amazing.  Everything about this model is perfect.  The river, the windows, the shrubs on the lawn, the gravel in the riverbed, the bridge... It's just wonderful.  It can't really be described. When you look at this set, you fell like you are IN Pennsylvania, looking at Frank Lloyd Wright's masterpiece.  If you like beautiful lego sets, this MUST be in your collection.

author: LegoHov23
title: A Magnificent Set
review:
As an admirer of Frank Lloyd Wright and many of his designs I was excited to find this set in a store in New York, and I picked it up knowing that it would be my best opportunity to get a great set. Falling Waters did not disappoint.

Pros

  • Enjoyable building experience
  • Nice use of pieces; 1x2 blocks for the trees, 2x1 transparent blocks for the water, etc
  • Good use of grey baseplate
  • Special brick that says "Fallingwater" on it
  • Actual building split into different components
  • Nice box
  • Excellent manual with clear instructions & pictures of the real thing, as well as quotes from FLW himself
  • Looks stunning

Cons

  • Not much for playing; more of a display set
  • Slightly expensive, although the aesthetics are worth it
Overall, one of my favorite LEGO sets; nice build and beautiful to look at. I wouldn't recommend it to someone looking for playability but for a collector, architecture enthusiast or anyone who displays their LEGO this set is perfect.

author: tomalphin
title: An acceptable facsimile of an unbelievable Architectural Masterpiece.
review:
Impressions of the real building: I had a chance to visit Fallingwater about 14 years ago, and would very much like to go back.  It is a marvelous building by the only architect I can think of who is flexible enough to reinvent his style over and over again.  The way the building "plays" with it's surrounding landscape is art, the stream gives it a musical character.  While the built-in furniture is reminiscent of his Prairie homes, the design is undeniably in the "modern" style - unadorned, rectangular and open.

Impressions of this set: Fallingwater was the first "big" set in the LEGO Architecture series, and I have long been a bit hesitant to build this model as the photos I've seen of the model didn't speak to me.  I think my main objection is that the tan color and extensive use of 1x2 Panels and 1x1 corner panels draws too much attention to the seams between individual LEGO bricks.  I've built nearly every other official Architecture set, and I was able to a used copy of the set inexpensively, so it was time to finally build the model!

Building experience: The first hour of construction really dragged on for me, since easily half of the model is the landscaping base with the water feature.  Worse still, the construction technique for the base seems haphazard and isn't especially strong.  (It doesn't help that it's built on a flimsy 16x32 plate, which doesn't match the rest of the series.)

Thankfully, the construction for the building itself is a little more engaging, largely due to the fact that you are finally constructing the actual building, and while there is no advanced techniques used here (SNOT, etc...), it is interesting to finally see the *trick* which is employed in the last few steps of the construction.  [I hadn't read any spoilers so I won't offer any either...]

Suffice it to say that the construction process is a bit boring and employs a lot of the same simple parts and techniques, but it was still fun to complete.

Finished Model: The final model is a bit better than my initial impression, although it falls short of the level of refinement in more recent models in the series, especially the UN Headquarters and the Imperial Hotel.  I would have liked to see less bricks and time dedicated to the landscaping, and more to the model itself.  The part selection and massive number of tan bricks is monotonous and uninspiring.

Conclusion: While Fallingwater is a masterstroke by one of the World's finest architects, this is a somewhat lackluster model in an exceptional series.  There are many ways that they could have made this stand out better, but the designer decided to focus on the overall form.  I do love the final steps of the construction where everything "comes together", but was left wishing for something which better captures the original.

Using the instructions, this model took about 2.5 hours to complete. I had to follow the instructions very carefully as there are some extremely redundant steps along the way.

 

About me: I am an AFOL who has built a couple sets each year for my whole life. I build most sets under 500 pieces as a "puzzle build" without using the instructions. I used the instructions for this model as it would be impractical to build it any other way.

I have built all of the smaller LEGO Architecture sets (about 20 sets so far), and this is my the second of the three large sets. (I recently built the Imperial Hotel, but haven't built Robie House yet...)

author: Cheeze_ball
title: Nice Looking Set
review: Very nice looking set. The build is very straight forward; there's only two instances of SNOT. I appreciate the house itself can be removed to reveal its levels. Great set for what it is, but I don't know how to improve upon it. It's a very basic set for an architecture icon. I bought it for MSRP, but don't feel it's quite worth its current value.
